An old teacher once said it’s better to grow up learning only one language because apparently the lack of whatever other one you’d be able to communicate in would make up for how much better you’d be in your native language.

    And I don’t think he could’ve been more wrong so here’s an analogy explaining why.

    Let’s say every person has a certain amount of resources available, which I shall refer to as “blocks”. Over the course of your life you will take these blocks and place them in your “skill fields”. In this example our skill fields are different languages, and on each skill field you can aquire “points” by placing more blocks on them.

    Placing one block on a skill field, will grant you 50 points. Those would be about equal to knowing the basics of a language ( = general everyday mostly fluid talk, but you couldn’t be an author yet). Every additional block on the same skill field will grant you only 10 more points.

    So let’s say you have 3 blocks available for your language skill fields. You could place all your blocks on English, which would grant you 70 points. Or you could place the 1st on English, 2nd on German, 3rd on…. Japanese. Therefore you get 50 points per skill field which in total adds up to 150 points, more than double the amount of what you get by placing them all on only one field!

    Not very good at endings, do with this information whatever you like.

    Also I like colours… sorry if they are overwhelming.

    Started out this analogy with “… every person starts out in life with a certain limited amount of balls”
